article_title: The Sieges of Mazagan: A History of Conflict and Transformation

paragraphs.text: Mazagan, now known as El Jadida, was founded by King Emmanuel of Portugal in 1514 . The toponym 'Mazagan' is possibly of Berber origin, with forms such as 'Mazighan' appearing in texts from the 11th and 12th centuries . Duarte Pacheco Pereira described Mazagan around the beginning of the 16th century, noting the location of a destroyed city . In the summer of 1514, construction of the castle of Mazagan accelerated under Portuguese military protection . Some strategists questioned the need for a fortress at Mazagan given the fortress being built at Azamor . Mazagan began as a small protectorate of the Portuguese crown in 1486 . After the conquest of Azamor in 1513, King Manuel I ordered the transformation of Mazagan into a bastioned fortress to protect the Carreira da Índia . In 1541, Mazagan was transformed into a grand fortress city, considered the first 'ideal city' of the Renaissance built outside of Europe .

Around 1540, the building of the bastioned fortress of Mazagan in North Africa marked a turning point in Portuguese fortification . The hiring of an Italian engineer played a major role in the construction of the Mazagan fortress . The experimental process and knowledge transfer involved in the construction of Mazagan went beyond a simple technical delivery from the center to the periphery . In 1541, Benedetto da Ravenna inspected Portuguese cities in Morocco, including Septa, Tangier, and Mazagan . Benedetto da Ravenna's plan for Mazagan is considered the first perfect European bulwarked fortification . In 1541, Benedetto da Ravenna and Miguel de Arruda visited Mazagão to modernise the fortifications . Francisco de Holanda drew the initial model for the fortifications at Mazagão applying the bastion system, though he never visited Mazagão himself . The construction of angled bastions in Mazagão started in 1541, potentially impacting discussions on fort design .

Administrative records related to Mazagan from 1541 reveal the difficulty in obtaining good lime for the new ramparts, with lime being considered more reliable than earth filling . The cistern in Mazagan was built between 1541 and 1547 . The fortress in Mazagão resisted local armies until 1769, at which point it was abandoned due to a long siege and the inability to maintain a garrison .

Attacks and sieges on the fortress of Mazagan were frequent throughout its history . Attacks occurred in 1517, and in 1521, Portugues and Moors perished under the walls . In 1525, the King of Fez laid siege to Mazagan . In March 1561, there was a battle after the son of the Sharif demanded the keys to the fortress . In 1562, Agostinho de Gavy de Mendonça's book "Historia do famoso cerco..." describes a siege of Mazagan . In 1562, during the defense of Mazagan by Mulay Abdallah's forces, the poem 'De bello Mazagonico' was created, portraying Saadi rulers negatively . Antonio Lopes' poem 'De bello Mazagonico' drew inspiration from Aeschylus' 'The Persians' in its depiction of Muslim rulers .

In 1578, following the Battle of the Three Kings, Moulay esh-Sheykh, a son of the defeated sultan of Morocco, sought refuge in Mazagan, which was then held by the Portuguese . From Mazagan, Moulay esh-Sheykh traveled to Lisbon at the end of December 1578 under the protection of the Portuguese .

In 1623, over 10,000 Moors attacked Mazagan . Gonçalo Coutinho, governor of Mazagan from 1624 to 1627, left detailed descriptions of the ribat of Tit . In 1640, the Captain and over 100 Portuguese cavalry died in combat .

Two documents titled "Noticia da grande batalha..." (1757) and "Noticia do grande assalto e batalha..." (1756) report on battles and assaults on Mazagan in February 1757 and June 1756 respectively . In 1768, a Moroccan army of 75,000 soldiers besieged Mazagan . In December 1768, the King of Morocco declared Jihad against Mazagan . The Moroccan army, consisting of 120,000 men supported by French military engineers, besieged Mazagan . The Governor of Mazagan prevented the Portuguese from leaving the fortress to defend themselves . On January 30, Moulay Mohammed sent messengers to demand the keys of the city to avoid war .

Mazagan was the last Portuguese city in the Maghreb, abandoned in 1769 . Mazagan was the only Portuguese establishment remaining on the Atlantic coast of Morocco . The abandonment of Mazagan was decided in January 1769 by the Marquis de Pombal and the King of Portugal . On March 11, 1769, the Portuguese evacuated Mazagan . On March 11, 1769, the entire population of Mazagan was forced to abandon the city and return to Lisbon . On March 1, 1769, a fleet of 14 ships arrived from Lisbon with instructions for the abandonment of the city . The fleet had departed from Lisbon on February 3, 1769 . A truce was established with the besieging forces on March 9, 1769 . The population of Mazagan was told that the abandonment was for their own safety from the 'barbarity of the Moors' .

The population of Mazagan at the time of evacuation was approximately 2100 people, under the governance of Dinis Gregorio de Melo e Castro Mendonça . Approximately 2,100 people, comprising 460 families, 31 single soldiers, and 4 priests, sailed for Lisbon . Women, children, invalids, and the sick were evacuated first . Sacred images, silverware, and church ornaments were prioritized during the evacuation . Carriages were burned, iron cannons were thrown into the sea, and walls and buildings were exploded to leave only ruins . On March 8, 1769, embarkation occurred through the 'Porte de la Mer' . The Portuguese destroyed a bastion in Mazagan as they withdrew, killing hundreds of Muslim soldiers . In 1769, there were approximately 200 horses in Mazagan . The city's fortifications had walls that were twelve meters wide . In 1769, Mazagan had five churches, eight small chapels, and fifteen priests . Colonel Carlos Julião, a military officer who participated in the 1769 mission, recalled being part of the expedition against the 'contagious society' of Mazagan .

The 2100 evacuees were intended to help populate the Amazon . The abandonment of Mazagan was part of a larger plan by Pombal to secure Portuguese interests in the Amazon, seeing the city as a drain on resources . The Portuguese community of Mazagan was deported to the Amazon . On March 11, 1769, the Portuguese community left Mazagan on 12 ships for Lisbon under the order of King Joseph and the Marquis of Pombal . In 1769, 371 families (2000 people) embarked from Lisbon to Para on nine ships on September 15 . They arrived in Belém do Para in early January 1770 . From 1772, the inhabitants of Mazagan were gradually transferred to Nova Mazagão . The Mazagan population was relocated to Vila Nova de Mazagão in the Amazon region of Brazil in 1771 after a delay and poor treatment in Lisbon . In 1775, five years after their arrival to Brazil, there were still 68 Mazagan families awaiting relocation in Belém . The new city of Mazagão in Brazil was designed by Domingo Sambuceti and officially founded in 1771 .

Sultan Muhammad III renamed Mazagan to El-Mahduma ('destroyed') after the Portuguese withdrawal and destruction . Mazagan became El-Mahduma ('The Destroyed') and remained empty for 50 years . Later Moroccan rulers worked to rebuild Mazagan, eventually renaming it El-Jadida ('new' or 'renewed') . Around 1820, Jewish merchants requested permission to settle there, and the city was rebuilt and renamed El Jadida ('The New') . In 1821, the city was renamed El Jadida (the New) . In 1822, Alawite rulers commissioned the rebuilding of the connection to the mainland and new city walls in El-Jadida . Christian families were permitted to settle in El-Jadida and practice their religion . The arrival of a Jewish community in the mid-19th century contributed to the cosmopolitan image of El-Jadida .

Sultan alaouite Sidi Muhammad ben Abd Allah rebuilt Casablanca in the 18th century after the Portuguese evacuated Mazagan in 1769 . The rebuilding of Casablanca was partly motivated by the fear of a Christian counter-offensive after the evacuation of Mazagan . Sidi Muhammad ben Abd Allah sought to fill the defensive gap between Rabat and Mazagan by rebuilding Casablanca .

El Jadida obtained UNESCO World Heritage status in 2004 under the name "Ville portugaise de Mazagan (El Jadida)" . Hassan II and Muhammad VI sought UNESCO recognition for the fortress of El-Jadida to promote tourism . Mazagan (now El Jadida) has been a UNESCO heritage site since 2004 . In 2004, the Portuguese City of Mazagan (El Jadida) was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List . Mazagan was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2004 .

The Mazagan Beach Resort, a single hotel in the Mazagan complex, advertises car transfers from Casablanca Airport . Mazagan, located near El Jadida, was one of the five resorts planned for the Atlantic coast as part of the Plan Azur . The Plan Azur aimed to create six new coastal resorts, but only Mediterrania Saïdia (opened in 2009) and Mazagan (opened in spring 2010) were realized . The Mazagan resort is located about an hour south of Casablanca and is served by Casablanca's airport .
